# Task

Write a function `wrap_string`. It iterates over words and it will add a new line each time a maximum `text_width::Int=10` would be exceeded. Provide an example



# Special Instructions

{{instructions}}

Given the task description and the special instructions, here is how I would approach solving this problem using Julia:

```julia
function wrap_string(text::AbstractString; text_width::Int=10)
    lines = []
    current_line = ""
    for word in split(text)
        if length(current_line) + length(word) > text_width
            push!(lines, current_line)
            current_line = ""
        end
        current_line *= word * ' '
    end
    push!(lines, current_line)
    return join(lines, "\n")
end

# Example usage:
text = "Hello there this is a very long sentence that should be wrapped at 10 characters per line."
wrapped_text = wrap_string(text)
println(wrapped_text)
```

This function splits the text into words using `split`, then iterates over each word. It checks if adding the current word to the current line would exceed the specified `text_width`. If so, it adds the current line to the list of lines and starts a new line. After all words have been processed, it joins the lines back together with a newline character between each one.

The example usage demonstrates how the function can be called with a default value for `text_width` and prints out the wrapped text.
